subject: Re: [junit] Test case strategy for complex tests
msgSnippet: ... I assume you mean JDBC client code, and nothing about EJBs (the EJB just happens to be your JDBC client). Correct me if that is wrong. Usually I recommend:
messageBody:
mirumoto_kojiro wrote:

> I'm writing test cases for EJB's and some of the beans do some complex SQL
> generation and return large amounts of data, Realizing that test cases
> should be
> simple... Should I just test that the query runs without error and not
> worry about the
> return? Or should I check certain parts to make sure thay are right?
> Or check the
> entire result set?

I assume you mean JDBC client code, and nothing about EJBs (the EJB just
happens to be your JDBC client). Correct me if that is wrong.

Usually I recommend:

1. Verify that the SQL command returns the proper results "by hand"
against sample test data.
2. Verify that you generate the SQL command correctly using String
comparisons against the SQL command you tested in step 1.
3. Verify that you set up the PreparedStatement/CallableStatement
correctly (the right parameters).
4. Verify that you invoke executeUpdate() or executeQuery() and clean up
your JDBC resources.

> Question#2: I have many SQL queries with multiple possiblities in the
> WHERE clause.
> They are being built on the fly based on the search criteria given by a
> user. I was
> going to test each WHERE clause in a seperate test.

Good idea.

>Should I write the
> tests in such a
> way that I could combine calls to them and have a test case that is more
> of a
> controller pattern?

Prefer isolated tests.
